channel.title: How to save data to an online server?
channel.description:
How can I save a string or w/e in a file on a server?
For example: I have a script on a 50webs website, which I want to save stuff in the directory there, how would I do that? I can save just on my own pc...

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

It does have an ftp map though, but if that’s the error, tyvm for helping - I guess i’ll just have to find an other than ;)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: February 25, 2008, 02:13:59 PM[/size][hr]anyone knows a webhoster that does support FTP?

Read full topic

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“supamagier, post:37, topic:183560”]I created the file, but it still goes to IOException…

btw, I can’t debug shit if I don’t know how to… and this forum is for java programming help…[/quote]Yes but we still hope you have atleast a mild understanding and can supply information about the exact error.

If this isn’t working for you, then find a cheap webhost and make a PHP file to do the transfer. Host the PHP script on your webspace and have Java connect to that.

Also, out of curiosity, what Java version are you using?

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

Let's say I have the string "This is a string". I want that string to be saved in the above called file, test.txt, in the online map. So in fact, I need: [code]BufferedWriter file = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("./testStuff/test.txt")); file.write("This is a string"); file.close(); [/code] But that so that I can save it on a ftp server.

Please help me out, and please don’t flame on me… that makes no sense

Thanks,

~Supamagier

PS: With that bos.write, I can’t write strings… O_o or can I?

The file needs to be written already in the classpath, it can’t be nonexistant, your actually uploading a physical file. Also, debug your own shit.

Read full topic

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

I tried it all, none of it worked. Either I’m doing something wrong, or there’s something wrong with your code.

My code:

try {
	    
	        BufferedOutputStream bos = new BufferedOutputStream(new URL("ftp://" + "username" + ":" + "pass" + "@" + "ice-swizzy.50webs.com/" + "ice-swizzy.50webs.com/Read/testStuff/" + "test.txt" + ";type=i").openConnection().getOutputStream());
            bos.close();
    }
        catch (IOException ioexception) {
            checkField.setText("ERROR");
            }

When I use this it goes to the catch () and it sets the text ERROR in my checkField…

The link to the ftp map:
ftp://ice-swizzy.50webs.com/ice-swizzy.50webs.com/Read/testStuff/
I want the file to be called test.txt

I’ll reprase my question:

[quote]
Let’s say I have the string “This is a string”.
I want that string to be saved in the above called file, test.txt, in the online map.
So in fact, I need:

BufferedWriter file = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("./testStuff/test.txt")); file.write("This is a string"); file.close();
But that so that I can save it on a ftp server.

Please help me out, and please don’t flame on me… that makes no sense

Thanks,

~Supamagier

PS: With that bos.write, I can’t write strings… O_o or can I?

Read full topic
item.source: How to save data to an online server?

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

Picky bastards, although it wasn’t very good code (goes to show what late nights produce)…

    public void upload(String serverPath, String ftpServer, String user, String pwd, String fileName, File source) throws Exception {
            BufferedOutputStream bos = new BufferedOutputStream(new URL("ftp://" + user + ":" + pwd + "@" + ftpServer + serverPath + fileName + ";type=i").openConnection().getOutputStream());
            BufferedInputStream bis = new BufferedInputStream(new FileInputStream(source));
            int i;
            while ((i = bis.read()) != -1) {
                bos.write(i);
            }
            bis.close();
            bos.close();
    }

Read full topic

item.source: How to save data to an online server?

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:28, topic:183560”][quote author=k00dr link=topic=245259.msg2072964#msg2072964 date=1203825311]

Upload method, probably easier considering you don’t want to use your brain and debug your own code.:

    public void upload(String ftpServer, String user, String pwd, String fileName, File source, String serverPath) throws MalformedURLException,
            IOException {

        if (ftpServer != null && fileName != null && source != null) {
            StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("ftp://");
            if (user != null && pwd != null) {
                sb.append(user);
                sb.append(':');
                sb.append(pwd);
                sb.append('@');
            }
            sb.append(ftpServer);
            sb.append(serverPath); //Sets the folder on the server
            sb.append(fileName);
            sb.append(";type=i"); //a=ASCII mode, i=image (binary) mode, d= file directory listing

            BufferedInputStream bis = null;
            BufferedOutputStream bos = null;
            try {
                URL url = new URL(sb.toString());
                URLConnection urlc = url.openConnection();

                bos = new BufferedOutputStream(urlc.getOutputStream());
                bis = new BufferedInputStream(new FileInputStream(source.getName()));

                int i;
                while ((i = bis.read()) != -1) {
                    bos.write(i);
                }
            } finally {
                if (bis != null) {
                    try {
                        bis.close();
                    } catch (IOException ioe) { /* ignore*/ }
                }
                if (bos != null) {
                    try {
                        bos.close();
                    } catch (IOException ioe) { /* ignore*/ }
                }
            }
        }
    }

Way2Use a StringBuilder when it is not needed.

wtf
[/quote]
Does he REALLY need to use a StringBuilder when he’s already null checked the Strings? No.[/quote]

He was using a StringBuffer not a StringBuilder >.<

Read full topic

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:29, topic:183560”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=245259.msg2073225#msg2073225 date=1203834123]

Upload method, probably easier considering you don’t want to use your brain and debug your own code.:

    public void upload(String ftpServer, String user, String pwd, String fileName, File source, String serverPath) throws MalformedURLException,
            IOException {

        if (ftpServer != null && fileName != null && source != null) {
            StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("ftp://");
            if (user != null && pwd != null) {
                sb.append(user);
                sb.append(':');
                sb.append(pwd);
                sb.append('@');
            }
            sb.append(ftpServer);
            sb.append(serverPath); //Sets the folder on the server
            sb.append(fileName);
            sb.append(";type=i"); //a=ASCII mode, i=image (binary) mode, d= file directory listing

            BufferedInputStream bis = null;
            BufferedOutputStream bos = null;
            try {
                URL url = new URL(sb.toString());
                URLConnection urlc = url.openConnection();

                bos = new BufferedOutputStream(urlc.getOutputStream());
                bis = new BufferedInputStream(new FileInputStream(source.getName()));

                int i;
                while ((i = bis.read()) != -1) {
                    bos.write(i);
                }
            } finally {
                if (bis != null) {
                    try {
                        bis.close();
                    } catch (IOException ioe) { /* ignore*/ }
                }
                if (bos != null) {
                    try {
                        bos.close();
                    } catch (IOException ioe) { /* ignore*/ }
                }
            }
        }
    }

Way2Use a StringBuilder when it is not needed.

wtf

Does he REALLY need to use a StringBuilder when he’s already null checked the Strings? No.
[/quote]

String is immutable and creates a new String object every time you assign or concatenate to it. StringBuilder and StringBuffer are the fix for the inefficiency.[/quote]
How is it a fix? How is it inefficient?

Read full topic

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“speedster239, post:12, topic:183560”]Upload method, probably easier considering you don’t want to use your brain and debug your own code.:

[code]
public void upload(String ftpServer, String user, String pwd, String fileName, File source, String serverPath) throws MalformedURLException,
IOException {

    if (ftpServer != null && fileName != null && source != null) {
        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("ftp://");
        if (user != null && pwd != null) {
            sb.append(user);
            sb.append(':');
            sb.append(pwd);
            sb.append('@');
        }
        sb.append(ftpServer);
        sb.append(serverPath); //Sets the folder on the server
        sb.append(fileName);
        sb.append(";type=i"); //a=ASCII mode, i=image (binary) mode, d= file directory listing

        BufferedInputStream bis = null;
        BufferedOutputStream bos = null;
        try {
            URL url = new URL(sb.toString());
            URLConnection urlc = url.openConnection();

            bos = new BufferedOutputStream(urlc.getOutputStream());
            bis = new BufferedInputStream(new FileInputStream(source.getName()));

            int i;
            while ((i = bis.read()) != -1) {
                bos.write(i);
            }
        } finally {
            if (bis != null) {
                try {
                    bis.close();
                } catch (IOException ioe) { /* ignore*/ }
            }
            if (bos != null) {
                try {
                    bos.close();
                } catch (IOException ioe) { /* ignore*/ }
            }
        }
    }
}

[/code][/quote]
Way2Use a StringBuilder when it is not needed.

item.title: How to save data to an online server?
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:18, topic:183560”][quote author=supamagier link=topic=245259.msg2072206#msg2072206 date=1203773811]
The exception is IOException… (I have try { } catch (Exception IOException) { } and it goes to the catch so…)

Taharok, what does that mean?

And cheese, I’m using 50webs, which does provide ftp
[/quote]
The thing is, IOException inherits from Exception, so it’s all OK. But you may want to change the catch(…) to:

} catch (IOException ioException) { // exception handling code here }[/quote]

what’s the difference?
